title: 106_s1704
content: The "Access to High Standards Act" is the short title of this legislation. The "Access to High Standards Act" aims to address the lack of academic preparation in secondary schools, leading to limited employment opportunities and high college dropout rates. It emphasizes the importance of raising academic standards and setting high expectations to improve public education, drawing inspiration from advanced placement courses. The "Access to High Standards Act" advocates for modeling academic standards after advanced placement programs, which are endorsed by many education leaders and almost half of all States. These programs offer 30 college-level courses, are present in nearly 60% of secondary schools, and cater to over 1,000,000 students, with 80% in public schools, 55% females, and 30% minorities. Test scores from these programs are recognized for college credit at over 3,000 colleges and universities, including all universities in Germany, France, and Austria. Test scores from advanced placement programs are accepted for college credit at over 3,000 colleges and universities, as well as all universities in Germany, France, and Austria. Additionally, 24 States are funding programs to increase participation in advanced placement programs, including providing funds for teacher professional development, requiring public schools to offer advanced placement courses, paying fees for advanced placement tests, and mandating public schools to offer these courses. States have programs that fund advanced placement tests for students and require public universities to grant academic credit for passing scores. These programs have increased enrollment, raised academic standards, and improved minority participation in advanced placement courses. The Act aims to encourage more students to take advanced placement exams to demonstrate their achievements and benefit from important skills and higher SAT scores. The Act aims to support students in acquiring important skills, achieving higher SAT scores, and better grades in secondary school and college through advanced placement programs. It also aims to increase participation and success in these programs to raise academic standards. The Act aims to increase student participation and success in advanced placement programs by expanding availability, diversifying student participation, and demonstrating success with larger and more diverse groups of students. The Act aims to increase access to advanced placement courses for low-income and disadvantaged students, as well as for secondary school juniors in schools without such programs. It also aims to raise the participation rate of juniors and seniors in advanced placement courses to 25% of the student population. The Act aims to increase access to advanced placement courses for low-income and disadvantaged students, as well as for secondary school juniors and seniors. It aims to raise the participation rate in advanced placement courses to 25% of the student population and increase the number of students receiving college credit for their test scores. The Act aims to increase access to advanced placement courses for low-income and disadvantaged students, as well as for secondary school juniors and seniors, with the goal of raising participation rates to 25% of the student population and increasing the number of students receiving college credit for their test scores. SEC. 3. ADVANCED PLACEMENT PROGRAM GRANTS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities on a competitive basis to carry out authorized activities for a period of 3 years with annual payments. Eligible entities are defined in this section. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities on a competitive basis for 3 years with annual payments. Eligible entities are State or local educational agencies with a priority given to those demonstrating a need for advanced placement programs, involvement of business and community organizations, and availability of matching funds. The grant program prioritizes eligible entities with a focus on developing advanced placement programs in English, mathematics, and science, as well as involvement of business and community organizations, and availability of matching funds from State or local sources. The State educational agency implements programs targeting local educational agencies or schools with a high concentration of low-income students. Eligible entities can use grant funds to expand access to advanced placement programs for low-income individuals. An eligible entity can use grant funds to expand access to advanced placement incentive programs for low-income individuals, including teacher training, course development, curriculum coordination, supplies, and other related activities. Each eligible entity seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary, including data collection and reporting on the number of low-income students participating in advanced placement courses. The Secretary must collect data on the number of students taking advanced placement courses, the number of tests taken, test scores, and demographic information. The Secretary will compile an annual report on this data. The Secretary will collect data on students' performance in advanced placement courses, disaggregated by various demographics. This information will be compiled into an annual report for Congress. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following years. SEC. 4. ON-LINE ADVANCED PLACEMENT COURSES. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies for on-line advanced placement courses. Agencies can contract with organizations for course provision and support services. Priority is given to agencies serving low-income or rural students. The Secretary awards grants to local educational agencies for online advanced placement courses, prioritizing those serving low-income or rural students. The Secretary awards grants to local educational agencies for online advanced placement courses, prioritizing those serving low-income or rural students. Applicants must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following 4 years. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PRIORITIES FOR ADVANCED PLACEMENT. The institution of higher education must distribute information to secondary school counselors or advanced placement coordinators regarding academic credit for advanced placement test scores. Standardization of information dissemination must be achieved within 4 years of the enactment of this Act. The Act requires institutions of higher education to disseminate information to secondary school counselors or advanced placement coordinators about academic credit for advanced placement test scores. Standardization of information dissemination must be completed within 4 years of the Act's enactment. Additionally, amendments are made to the Javits gifted and talented students section of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Act amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to prioritize upward bound projects focusing on increasing secondary school student participation and success. It also includes provisions for programs and projects for gifted and talented students incorporating advanced placement courses and tests. The Act prioritizes upward bound projects that aim to increase secondary school student participation and success in advanced placement courses. Additionally, it gives priority to activities involving training in advanced placement instruction under the Eisenhower professional development program. The Act prioritizes activities that involve training in advanced placement instruction for grants and contracts under this part. State and local activities are also amended to include providing professional development activities. The Act emphasizes training in advanced placement instruction for grants and contracts, encouraging delivery to underserved communities. The Act defines terms like "advanced placement incentive program" as providing activities for low-income individuals and "advanced placement test" as a test approved by the Secretary. It also defines "high concentration of low-income students" in relation to educational agencies or schools. The term "low-income individual" refers to an individual from a family with incomes below the poverty level, as determined under specific education acts. An "individual" is a low-income individual who is academically prepared to take an advanced placement test, as determined by a school teacher or coordinator. An "institution of higher education" is defined as in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The terms "local educational agency", "secondary school", and "State educational agency" are defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and "State" includes the several States of the United States, the District of Columbia. The term "State" refers to each of the several States of the United States, the District of Columbia, and other territories like Puerto Rico, Guam, and American Samoa.
